body: It requires a feat of memory to picture gentrified Brooklyn -- that haven of stately homes, world-class cultural offerings and overpriced baby boutiques -- as it was a mere 40 years ago: a lost borough, Manhattan's poor, troubled relation. Consider, then, the near-hallucinatory vision it took at the time to imagine the Brooklyn of today. In the
title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED; Mothering Brooklyn: EVELYN ORTNER b. 1924

body: WEINBERG--Herschel. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President $(6$)WEINBERG--Herschel M., on December 26. Devoted son to the late Jacob and Gertrude. Beloved brother to
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINBERG, HERSCHEL

body: The body of a 47-year-old woman was found yesterday after an early morning fire in her home in East Flatbush, and her death has been ruled a homicide, the police said. The woman, Marie Bontemps, was found in her basement apartment at 1388 Troy Avenue. The medical examiner determined that she had been strangled, the police said. The fire, which has
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman's Body Is Found After Fire

body: They mourned James Brown the James Brown way yesterday: took his promotional poster and turned it into a shrine. There it stood outside B. B. King's nightclub on 42nd Street, a makeshift icon with the astral smile, the soul glow, the standing waves of anti-gravity hair. Where once the poster read, ''Appearing Live on New Year's Eve,'' it now said,
title: For Half a Century, a Legend Who Worked Up a Sweat

body: If all goes according to plan, work will begin within weeks on the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, which won final approval from a state oversight board on Wednesday after three years of furious debate. But large development projects rarely go according to plan -- even when they do not face multiple lawsuits, which the
title: Atlantic Yards Enters New Phase, and Faces Next Hurdle: Lawsuits

body: With a wisdom and honesty that seemed precocious for a 10th grader, Shadie Thompson, 15, lowered her eyes and explained why she should not live with her parents in their apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn. ''I don't want to go through all that again,'' she said solemnly, describing as best she could what it was like to watch her mother, Sarah
title: The Neediest Cases; As Parents Regain Health, A Girl, 15, Is Free to Dream

body: In taking care of his ailing parents around-the-clock, Brian Jemmotte sometimes neglected to take care of himself. And that would often lead to seizures -- some mild and some life threatening. ''I know when one's coming,'' said Mr. Jemmotte, 40, a lumbering 6-foot-tall man, wearing a Yankees cap that shadowed his boyish face. ''The sky gets dark.
title: The Neediest Cases; Stepping Out on His Own After Caring for Ill Parents

body: THE REV. AL SHARPTON and I don't have much in common -- you could argue that's a blessing for both of us -- but we do share a defining backdrop for our wonder years in Brooklyn. At different times, we both attended Samuel J. Tilden High School. And both of us were chagrined by the announcement Monday by the New York City Department of Education
title: CITY LORE; When Tilden Was the World

body: There's a certain facial expression, a mix of anguish and unsated desire, that Sonia Gordon knows she will see each time she tells one of her customers that her restaurant has run out of oxtail stew. ''People leave work, and oxtail is on their mind,'' said Ms. Gordon, the owner and the cook at Stir It Up, a West Indian restaurant on Atlantic Avenue
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Mouths Water For a Treat Turned Scarce

body: Jan Jarvis is 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 230 pounds. At first, he seems sullen and imposing, especially dressed in a dark-blue security guard uniform. But coaxing a smile out of Mr. Jarvis is not difficult, a remarkable achievement after a life of sexual abuse, unfocused rage and homelessness. With counseling and several hospitalizations for
title: The Neediest Cases; After Self-Destructive Descent, a Man Finds a Rung to Grasp: Therapy

body: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City, selected by Vivien Schweitzer. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) More holiday events this weekend are in The Listings on Pages 34 to 38. (Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)
title: Sounds of the Season From Churches and Halls

body: Around Town Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. Tomorrow, 5 to 8:30 p.m., candlelight tours, with demonstrations of holiday customs from the 17th to the 19th centuries, including a Wassail reception, $27.50; members, $22. Reservations required: (718) 351-1611, Ext. 281.

body: Will Self's new novel, ''The Book of Dave'' (Bloomsbury USA), is about a London cabdriver who inadvertently founds a religion when a ranting diatribe he buries in the garden of his ex-wife is dug up five centuries later, in a now post-apocalyptic world, and becomes a sacred text. Mr. Self's own text is immensely learned in cabbie lore and even
title: A Literary Visitor Strolls In From the Airport

body: The bus from Miami rolled into the Port Authority station at 6:25 p.m. Thursday, 28 hours after Marie Rose Dorismond set out for New York City, alone on her grim pilgrimage. It was not the first time she had returned to the place she fled after her only son, Patrick M. Dorismond, was killed at age 26 by the police in 2000; she comes back every Feb.
title: Police Shooting Reunites Circle of Common Loss

body: A 25-year-old man who pulled a knife on another man during a fight over a parking spot in Brooklyn was shot and killed yesterday, the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, got into the dispute about 3:30 p.m. outside a restaurant on Flatbush Avenue in Flatlands. According to the police, the victim was arguing with two men over a
title: Man Killed Over Parking Spot in Brooklyn

body: Muriel Castanis, a sculptor whose fluidly draped figures are displayed in public places and galleries around the United States, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 80 and lived in Greenwich Village. The cause was lung failure, her husband, George Castanis, said. A self-taught artist, Ms. Castanis was known in particular for her method of laying
title: Muriel Castanis, 80, Sculptor of Draped Forms

body: Everything looked good for the palatial Loew's Kings Theater in Flatbush, Brooklyn, for all of about six weeks, the period between its opening on Sept. 7, 1929, and the stock market crash known as Black Thursday. The ensuing Great Depression would quickly render it a palace of misplaced optimism. The vaudeville acts, which had performed twice a
title: Seeking a Champion for the Loew's Kings

title: Paid Notice: Deaths VERTLIEB, ISRAEL (SONNY)

The man, 20, was shot in the back but ran almost a block on Church Avenue before he collapsed near 34th Street. He was taken to Kings County Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 9:15 p.m. The woman,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: One Dead, One Injured In Shooting

body: When Paul James, 18, of Brooklyn lost his mother, Amelia, six years ago, his heart and home broke apart. She died of breast cancer at 52, and her son was shuffled among relatives. Along the way, he grew into a man but retained a childlike longing for the stability he once had. ''I think about her every day,'' he said recently at the Brooklyn Bureau
title: The Neediest Cases; Through Loss and Uncertainty, a Young Man Persists on the Road to Independence

Born and raised in New York, New York. He had a long and fruitful career on Wall
title: Paid Notice: Deaths TISCHLER, EDMUND ISAAC

body: If you're making a list of election winners in New York, you might include James Madison High School in Brooklyn. Come January, when the new Congress convenes, Madison will be a rarity: a high school that can claim three sitting senators as alumni. Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont became No. 3 when he won a Senate seat this week, joining
title: NYC; A Wall of Fame Gets Crowded With Senators

body: A Ford Explorer hit another vehicle yesterday in Brooklyn, then careered onto a sidewalk, plowing into a mother and her three children walking to school, killing the woman's 5-year-old son before stopping about a block away, the police said. As the mother lay bleeding on the rain-slick sidewalk, screaming and moaning in pain, witnesses said they
title: S.U.V. Hits Mother and 3 Children on Sidewalk, Killing One

body: Joy Rolle, 30, of Brooklyn remembers when her contractions were coming stronger and closer together, before her water broke six years ago. It seemed like an eternity before she was wheeled into the delivery room. Her full-term pregnancy ended in an emergency Caesarean section because her son was in distress inside her womb. After recovery, she
title: The Neediest Cases; Help Meeting the Challenges of Parenthood and Poverty

body: COMING from a co-op in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Chaya and Simon Fridman, both 27, searched the Five Towns area of southwest Nassau County for their first house before settling last April on a three-bedroom, two-bath high ranch in Lawrence, a well-to-do suburb that in recent years has become a hub of Orthodox Jewish life. Ms. Fridman, a stay-at-home
title: LIVING IN/Lawrence, L.I.; One Idyllic Suburb, Two Parallel Universes

body: An 18-year-old man was shot yesterday on a street in Brooklyn and pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital Center, the police said. The man, Nathan Melville of Belmont Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn, was shot once in front of 1114 Flatbush Avenue in Flatbush. The police were called at 5:19 a.m. A Police Department spokesman said that officers
title: Young Man Fatally Shot on Brooklyn Street

body: Born in Brooklyn, Anthony Kap now lives in a FEMA trailer park that evokes the Bronx. His family's mobile home sits in the nearby community of Diamond, which apparently reminded some federal disaster official of a baseball diamond. Thus, gravel streets in the trailer park bear names like DiMaggio, Berra and Ford. Kap lives on Gehrig Drive, but he
title: FOOTBALL; A Mother Helps Her Son Find A Safe Harbor

body: One of those New York City bar guides prints helpful little symbols to describe each spot, and beside the entry for O'Connor's in Park Slope, there is a silhouette of a man diving into the water. A dive bar. Patrick O'Connor, the owner, hated that label. He didn't stand here all day, every day, running a cheap dump. And by the way, when his was the
title: PARK SLOPE JOURNAL; Same Old Bar? How Could It Be, Without Patrick?

body: OPENING THIS WEEK RUSSIAN TEA ROOM -- This fabled restaurant, which closed in 2002, is to reopen its ground-floor dining room for dinner on Friday. Lunch will follow in a few weeks. body: A 30-year-old man was fatally shot last evening in East Flatbush, the police said. The victim, identified as Shamel Williams, of East Flatbush, was shot once in the back around 5:15 p.m. by one of two men who fled in a vehicle near Rutland Road and Albany Avenue, investigators said. Mr. Williams was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed In Shooting

body: OLD Brooklyn was vanishing 100 years ago. Farms and small towns that had existed for several centuries were quickly giving way to factories, office buildings and housing developments in the most populous borough of the newly unified city. That is the Brooklyn that Clinton Irving Jones set out to preserve in photographs. From 1905 to 1911, he
title: BROOKLYN IN FOCUS; The Last Strains of a Pastoral Song

body: NOT since the Dodgers departed in 1957 has there been a slugfest in Brooklyn like the one over Atlantic Yards. The plan is colossal -- 16 high-rise buildings and an 18,000-seat basketball arena on 22 acres near the borough's busy downtown -- and fans and opponents have matched its magnitude with their own statistics. The developer, Forest City
title: On the Block

body: THE bench where 75-year-old Alvaro Fernandez was sitting when he was killed by a runaway van was gone Wednesday, two weeks to the day after the accident at the corner of Atlantic Avenue and Hoyt Street in Boerum Hill. A handmade memorial that had marked the spot was also gone, but a fire alarm box that the van had plowed over after jumping the curb
title: STREET LEVEL/BOERUM HILL; A Freeway Amid the Brownstones

body: Heather Woodbury's mother was reared in Flatbush, Brooklyn, where, she explained, ''you can't really have grown up and not have had the Dodgers be part of your life.'' body: The lower roadway of the Manhattan Bridge was closed yesterday for repairs that are expected to take a year, the city Transportation Department said. The repairs involve a complete rehabilitation of the lower road, according to a statement on the department's Web site. The upper level of the bridge, which connects Canal Street in Manhattan with
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Repairs To Manhattan Bridge

body: For decades, the only significant noise at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, New York City's first municipal airfield, which opened in 1931, has been the roar of jet engines heading to Kennedy International Airport. But next month, the sound of athletics is expected in a $38 million sports entertainment complex built by Aviator Sports and Recreation
title: SQUARE FEET; Soon a Home to Flying Pucks and Balls

title: POSTINGS; A New Condominium With a Familiar Ring

body: The tip of a crowbar jammed behind the big letter P, and all of a sudden, the place was just ''Pepper & OTTER.'' That never could have worked. title: BROOKLYN JOURNAL; A Car Dealership Defined By Big Dreams and Bigger Letters

body: Two men were shot to death in Brooklyn in separate attacks last night, the police said. In one shooting, a 39-year-old man was shot in the head at East 53rd Street and Snyder Avenue in East Flatbush. He was pronounced dead at the scene at 10:26 p.m. In the other, a 37-year-old man was shot several times during a dispute outside a building at 739
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Men Killed In Shootings

But customers in the neighborhood considered Taku to be a weekend and special occasion
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: The City Planning Commission is recommending that the developer Forest City Ratner reduce the size of its $4.2 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn by 8 percent, eliminating about 600 apartments but leaving the tallest tower in the complex untouched. At its meeting yesterday, the commission said the developer should cut back the massive
title: City Planners Recommend 8% Reduction in Atlantic Yards

body: PAUL FORD, a soft-spoken, sturdily built 32-year-old who works as an editor at Harper's Magazine, sometimes describes his commute between his apartment in Gowanus, Brooklyn, and his office on Broadway near Bond Street as feeling ''like a video game, except you can get killed.'' And in fact, watching Mr. Ford weave through the city's traffic-clogged
title: Queasy Rider

body: Across the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn early yesterday, in a public housing complex, a subway car and a packed nightclub, a handful of unrelated stabbings and shootings claimed the lives of two men and injured two more, according to the police. About 1 a.m., outside the Edenwald Houses, a public housing project at 1150 East 229th Street in the
title: In City, 2 Die and 2 Are Hurt In Attacks in a Span of Hours

body: THERE are women who can wax rhapsodic about their passion for vintage clothes, their eyes gleaming as they recount their purchase of a Pucci pantsuit for $10 at an estate sale in San Luis Obispo, Calif., in 1982 with the glittering avidity of Napoleon describing his conquest of Venice. I am not one of those women. In the past I have been able to
title: Critical Shopper; A Vintage Trip Through Brooklyn

body: Lloyd Ultan went looking for a Bronx neighborhood the other day called Williamsbridge. He was overqualified for this seemingly simple task. Mr. Ultan, the borough historian, teaches a course at Lehman College on the history of the Bronx and has written or co-written eight books about the borough. He even wrote the 182-word entry on Williamsbridge
title: Memories Fade, as Do Some Bronx Boundary Lines

body: BROOKLYN'S enthusiasts will tell you that the borough is like Paris in its long and distinguished literary tradition. And that consummate enthusiast, Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, has even been known to call it ''the new Left Bank.'' Tomorrow Mr. Markowitz's office has organized what he calls the first-ever Brooklyn Book Festival
title: Literary Voice, Brooklyn Accent

body: On This Brooklyn Route, The Next Stop Is History It sounds like a scene from ''The Twilight Zone.'' Cheerful, unsuspecting citizens board buses on a crowded block in Brooklyn. But these buses are not from the 21st century. They seem frozen in time: one from 1956, another from 1931, still another going back to 1917. They have no drivers. And they
title: Family Fare

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; A Flatiron On Flatbush

body: SHELDON GRUBER never met his grandfather Joseph Punn, a ceiling man from an era when pressed-tin ceilings could be found all over New York. But he has heard the stories. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST FLATBUSH; Tales Told in Tin

body: As New York City's nearly 1.1 million public-school students returned to class yesterday, Judi Aronson whizzed from school to school in her silver Toyota Camry, checking her BlackBerry at red lights. Over 34 years, she has been a teacher, a principal and, most recently, a superintendent. Yesterday she assumed a critical new role outside the
title: Day 1 in the Corridors of Learning for 1.1 Million Students

body: A 16-year-old girl and her boyfriend were arrested yesterday in the killing of her mother, who was found on Sunday in her Brooklyn apartment with her throat slit, the police said. The girl, Vintarra Martin, and the boyfriend, Damasoh Kelly, 24, of Columbus Avenue in Upper Manhattan, had fought with Ms. Martin's mother, Sharon Taylor, 41, at the
title: Couple Charged in Killing of Girl's Mother

title: DEVELOPER IS SAID TO PLAN CUTBACK IN YARDS PROJECT

body: A 41-year-old woman was found dead in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday with her throat slashed, the police said. A family member discovered the woman's body in a second-floor apartment on Rogers Avenue in Flatbush, the police said. The police did not release the victim's name. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Fatally Slashed

body: On the outside, the social club on a bustling strip of Church Avenue in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, looked like nothing special. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; For the Parade Before the Parade, Sequins and Panache

body: A city bus struck and killed a man in Flatlands, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, the police said. The pedestrian, Jack Kelly, 43, of Brooklyn, was crossing Flatbush Avenue near Avenue U about 2 p.m. when a B-47 bus heading south on Flatbush Avenue hit him and dragged him, the police said. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was
title: Pedestrian Killed in Brooklyn by a City Bus

body: An overflow crowd vehemently laid out the pros and cons of the proposed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn for seven hours last night at a raucous public meeting. Their passions suggested that opinions had only hardened in the three years since development plans were announced. ''This project essentially separates the neighborhoods of Brooklyn
title: Raucous Meeting on Atlantic Yards Plan Hints at Hardening Stances

body: Two-Track Soap Opera Q. I'm a fan of trains as well as opera, and I've heard it said that the Erie Railroad once had its headquarters in a New York opera house. Could this be true? A. Absolutely, and the story of the relationship is vividly told in ''Dark Genius of Wall Street,'' a biography of the railway magnate Jay Gould by Edward J. Renehan Jr.
title: F. Y. I.

body: The police seized 44,000 counterfeit DVD's and CD's, plus 39 DVD burners, on Tuesday at a residence on Flatbush Avenue, the police said yesterday. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Eight Arrested In Counterfeiting

title: To His Compatriots' Relief, Haitian Exile Is Arrested

title: Firefighters Endorse Clinton for Senate

body: A retired New York City police officer was seriously injured early yesterday when a woman drove up alongside the car he was driving on a Brooklyn street and shot him at least four times, the police said. Within hours, the victim's wife, herself a city police officer, was being held by the authorities in New Jersey in connection with the shooting.
title: Retired Police Officer Shot; Wife Is Held for Questioning

title: Forced to Move, Some Find Greener Grass

body: N.Y.P.D. Green Q. New York police cars are often black in old movies and photographs. When were they switched to the colors they are now? A. body: LUCA--Adolfo. On February 20, 2006. Adolfo was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1928 and was educated at Stuyvesant High School, New York University, and Harvard Law School. He was an attorney in private practice and then for NBC. Beloved husband of Betty for 50 years. Loving father of Mark, Robin Wilson and Rachel Busher. Dear fatherin-law of Larry and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LUCA, ADOLFO

body: The men on trial stare out from a screen like animated mug shots, images captured in fish-eye by cameras on Rikers Island. The screen is split to show two faces together yet apart, a backdrop to a courtroom where much appears in double. This is the second trial in the killing of a young college student; the first ended after a courtroom escape
title: Two Defendants, Two Juries And Horrors Spoken Twice

body: The Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of a proposed Brooklyn real estate project, can proceed with the demolition of six buildings it owns on the site, a state judge ruled yesterday. In an unusual move for a highly charged case turning on fine points of law, Justice Carol R. Edmead of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled from the bench
title: Demolition Can Proceed For Brooklyn Arena Project

body: Attractions Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., a discussion about the Negro Leagues, with Lawrence Hogan, a history professor, and the former Negro League players Armando Vasquez, Jim Robinson and Jose Pereira. Fee: $15; students and members, $12. Hours:
title: Spare Times

body: WENDY WASSERSTEIN, who died on Monday at 55 of complications of lymphoma, was celebrated as a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and a witty essayist, a dogged champion of the arts and a mentor to young playwrights. She was also a New Yorker through and through, the kind of New Yorker who was defined by the city as much as she defined it through her
title: THE WORDS; The Real Lady of the Canyons

body: SUESHOLTZ--Henrick Daniel ''Herb''. 91, Pioneer in TV and Picture - framing industries. Herb Suesholtz was born in Flatbush, Brooklyn in 1914. In 1935 he received a degree in chemical engineering from prestigious Cooper Union. During the war years he worked for RCA under an important government contract. Mr. Suesholtz was among the lead engineers
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SUESHOLTZ, HENRICK DANIEL ''HERB''

body: National stores have gotten a lot of attention by moving into New York City neighborhoods that were once thought of in the retailing world as about as hospitable as the moon: Old Navy in Harlem, Ikea in Red Hook, Target in Flatbush. But despite the headline-grabbing chain-store openings, the fact remains that New York City is dominated by locally
title: SQUARE FEET; A Retailing Czar, Looking Out for Mom and Pop

body: An apparently intoxicated off-duty police officer in street clothes who drew his gun after a group of men assaulted him was shot and critically wounded outside a Bronx fast-food restaurant early yesterday by an officer who mistook him for a criminal about to fire at a man lying at his feet, the authorities said. In a sequence caught by witnesses
title: Off-Duty Officer Is Shot by Police During Fight in Bronx

body: Over the past four years, Damion Henry has, in law enforcement parlance, become ''known to the police.'' In 2002, he was charged with shooting Officer Crystal Jeffrey, who was wounded in the arm as she walked back to her Brooklyn station house. He was later acquitted. In June, Mr. Henry, 25, fired shots into an East Flatbush restaurant, trying to
title: Police Shoot Brooklyn Man After He Fires, Officials Say

body: Each week, about 25,000 customers find their way by car, foot or public transportation to a five-month-old Home Depot store at 585 DeKalb Avenue, which sits on a five-acre site next to Public School 54, in a residential section of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. ''It's excitement all day long,'' said Ricky Campbell, the manager of the store, which
title: SQUARE FEET; Bringing a Big-Box Store to a Tough Area of Brooklyn

body: A 35-year-old police officer died yesterday after complaining of chest pains while responding to a report of gunshots, the authorities said. The officer, Francis Hennessy, left, collapsed when he got out of a patrol car at Farragut Road and Flatbush Avenue. He was pronounced dead at SUNY Downstate Medical Center. An autopsy was being conducted to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Officer Collapses And Dies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths GROTCH, HERBERT

body: A 24-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday morning as he walked through his old neighborhood in East Flatbush with his girlfriend, the police and the man's family said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot During A Fight

body: ''This is what traffic engineers consider a nightmare,'' said Samuel I. Schwartz, surveying the intersection of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues in Brooklyn on a cold night shortly before Thanksgiving. title: A Traffic Knot, Pulling Tighter
